original_data.question: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response:
The most common primary malignant bone tumor in children is osteosarcoma. The classic clinical presentation is pain at rest that is worse at night and is not relieved by anti-inflammatory agents. The painful "growing pain" in this case was caused by the tumor irritating the periosteum. The swelling and subsequent tenderness resulted from a hematoma from a bleed into the bone and soft tissue. The radiograph shows characteristic evidence of bone destruction and new bone formation. The biopsy shows small round blue cells, which is characteristic of Ewing sarcoma. Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that appears as a bump on the bone. Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that presents with pain that is relieved by aspirin. Ewing sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that presents with pain and a characteristic chromosomal translocation.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Advancing in extent or severity.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
The act of hindering or obstructing or impeding.
A readily reversible suspension of sensorimotor interaction with the environment, usually associated with recumbency and immobility.
Female parents, human or animal.
A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent with analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory properties
The time in every 24 hour period when it is dark.
Episodic childhood musculoskeletal pain, usually brief (a few minutes), intense, nocturnal, involving both legs, with no identifiable cause or sequelae.
Condition changed and/or recovered
Any period of seven consecutive days.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A competitive nine-member team sport including softball.
The region of the lower limb in animals, extending from the gluteal region to the FOOT, and including the BUTTOCKS; HIP; and LEG.
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A dull achy pain.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
Manner or style of walking.
White blood cells. These include granular leukocytes (BASOPHILS; EOSINOPHILS; and NEUTROPHILS) as well as non-granular leukocytes (LYMPHOCYTES and MONOCYTES).

A technique applicable to the wide variety of substances which exhibit paramagnetism because of the magnetic moments of unpaired electrons. The spectra are useful for detection and identification, for determination of electron structure, for study of interactions between molecules, and for measurement of nuclear spins and moments. (From McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of Science and Technology, 7th edition) Electron nuclear double resonance (ENDOR) spectroscopy is a variant of the technique which can give enhanced resolution. Electron spin resonance analysis can now be used in vivo, including imaging applications such as MAGNETIC RESONANCE IMAGING.
Used with organs, regions, and diseases for x-ray examinations.
The portion of the lower extremity between the knee and the ankle on the left side of the body.
The longest and largest bone of the skeleton, it is situated between the hip and the knee.
Pathological processes of the ADRENAL CORTEX.
A relatively thin sheetlike expanse or region lying over or under another.

A specialized CONNECTIVE TISSUE that is the main constituent of the SKELETON. The principal cellular component of bone is comprised of OSTEOBLASTS; OSTEOCYTES; and OSTEOCLASTS, while FIBRILLAR COLLAGENS and hydroxyapatite crystals form the BONE MATRIX.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.
Femur, each instance of which articulates with some left hip bone, left patella and left tibia.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
